questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of developmental delay. He could sit alone at 12 months and started walking with support at the age of 2 years. He can name only very few familiar objects and uses simple two-word sentences. He cannot stack more than 2 blocks. His parents report that he does not like playing with other children. He is at the 90th percentile for head circumference, 85th percentile for height, and 50th percentile for weight. He has a long and narrow face, a prominent chin and large protruding ears. His thumbs can be passively flexed to the ipsilateral forearm. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gynecomastia, as well as tall stature and testicular hypoplasia, are hallmark symptoms of Klinefelter syndrome, a chromosomal condition that typically manifests at the onset of puberty due to testicular dysgenesis and subsequent testosterone deficiency. Young children are typically tall for their age, may have mild learning difficulties, but are otherwise asymptomatic and reach their developmental milestones. Fragile X syndrome is not associated with gynecomastia.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk of developing acute leukemia is increased 10- to 100-fold in patients with Down syndrome (DS). Children with DS usually present with muscular hypotonia within the first 12 months of life and generally fail to reach their developmental milestones. While developmental delay is common and joint hypermobility may occur, the dysmorphic facial features in patients with DS (e.g., upward slanting eyelids and small, low-set ears) differ from the features this patient has. Fragile X syndrome is not associated with acute leukemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Hearing loss occurs in up to 95% of patients with neurofibromatosis type 2 as a result of bilateral acoustic neuromas. Individuals with this condition are at an increased risk of developing CNS neoplasms in adulthood. Children typically develop normally without any external signs or developmental delay or facial disproportion. Fragile X syndrome is not associated with hearing loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic dissection is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patient's with Marfan syndrome. Above average height and joint hypermobility are common findings in Marfan syndrome, but developmental delay, autistic behavior, and intellectual disability would not be expected. Fragile X syndrome is not associated with aortic dissection.

E) INCORRECT:

Type 2 diabetes mellitus, as well as sleep apnea, and cardiovascular disease are common obesity-related complications in young adults with Prader-Willi syndrome. Muscular hypotonia and genital hypoplasia are classic findings in infancy, and young children quickly become obese due to hyperphagia. Short stature is another common finding, whereas this patient's height is above average. Although children may have some cognitive impairment and achieve developmental milestones later than expected, behavioral problems (e.g., temper tantrums) are more prominent, and different facial dysmorphic features (e.g., almond-shaped eyes and thin upper lip) would be expected. Fragile X syndrome is not associated with diabetes mellitus.

F) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia occurs in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome as a result of an enzyme deficiency. Depending on the degree of deficiency, patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome may present with developmental delay. However, neurologic symptoms (e.g., choreoathetoid movements) usually occur by 8–12 months of age and self-injurious behavior would also be expected. Moreover, a long and narrow face, protruding ears, and an above-average height and head circumference are not consistent with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Fragile X syndrome is not associated with hyperuricemia.

G) CORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is present in about half of all patients with fragile X syndrome and while it is usually a benign condition, it may lead to mitral regurgitation. In fact, MVP is the most common valvular cause of chronic mitral regurgitation. Patients with fragile X syndrome are also at increased risk of developing focal seizures, which occur in 10–20% of cases. The underlying mutation of the FMR1 gene leads to imbalances of neurotransmission, causing neuronal hyperexcitability. The seizures can be with or without impaired awareness. The majority of cases have a good prognosis and seizures resolve spontaneously during childhood.
questions.hint: This boy's delayed development, autistic behavior, long and narrow face with a prominent chin, protruding ears, and above average head circumference indicate fragile X syndrome. Affected individuals often present with hypermobility of their joints and intellectual disability.

questions.text: A 6-week-old girl is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has had difficulty feeding with frequent regurgitation of milk and her mother is concerned that the child is not gaining weight appropriately. The mother reports that the girl's crying resembles a squeaky door. She is at the 2nd percentile for head circumference, 30th percentile for height, and 15th percentile for weight. Examination shows mandibular hypoplasia, a broad nasal bridge, widely-spaced eyes, and a round face. The palpebral fissures are down-slanting and she has a single palmar crease. A 3/6 pansystolic murmur is heard along the left lower sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Microdeletion of the short arm at chromosome 5 causes cri-du-chat syndrome, which explains this patient's developmental and physical abnormalities. Only symptomatic treatment (largely through psychosocial assistance) is available. Most patients have a normal life expectancy unless cardiac abnormalities are significant. This patient should have an echocardiogram to diagnose her heart murmur.

Most cases of cri-du-chat syndrome are sporadic, not inherited.

B) INCORRECT:

An X-linked dominant gene mutation can be the cause of Rett syndrome (although most cases result from a sporadic mutation), which often manifests with poor growth in a young girl. However, Rett syndrome is often diagnosed in previously healthy girls 2–18 years old with new onset speech loss and motor abnormalities (e.g., teeth grinding, characteristic hand wringing). Moreover, it does not explain this patient's craniofacial abnormalities or the high-pitched cry.

C) INCORRECT:

Translocation of chromosome 21 is a very rare cause of Down syndrome (trisomy 21 is by far the most common cause). Although patients with Down syndrome can also present with failure to thrive, a single palmar crease, and craniofacial abnormalities, this patient's high-pitched cry is characteristic of another disease. Additionally, Down syndrome is associated with upward-slanting, not downward-slanting, palpebral fissures.

D) INCORRECT:

Trisomy of chromosome 13 causes Patau syndrome, which can also manifest with craniofacial abnormalities (e.g., microcephaly, small chin) and cardiac defects (as suggested by this patient's heart murmur). However, Patau syndrome typically causes polydactyly, cleft lip/palate, and hypotelorism (rather than hypertelorism). Also, Patau syndrome would not explain this patient's high-pitched cry or the single palmar crease.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive prenatal alcohol exposure may result in fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), which can manifest with many of this patient's abnormalities (e.g., failure to thrive, heart defect, microcephaly, downward-slanting palpebral fissure, hypertelorism). However, this patient's high-pitched cry is characteristic of another disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Maternal hypothyroidism can cause transient congenital hypothyroidism, which can also manifest with failure to thrive and feeding problems and is associated with a slightly increased rate of cardiac defects. However, patients with congenital hypothyroidism typically have an increased head circumference and a hoarse cry rather than this patient's high-pitched cry. Additionally, hypothyroidism would not explain this patient's craniofacial abnormalities.
questions.hint: Failure to thrive, difficulty feeding, a high-pitched cry, and a suspected congenital heart defect (possibly a ventricular septal defect) in a child with dysmorphic facial features is suggestive of cri-du-chat syndrome.

questions.text: A 3466-g (7-lb, 10-oz) female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8, at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has a history of schizophrenia and was treated with lithium until 5 weeks' gestation, when she found out that she was pregnant. The mother was treated for alcohol use disorder 2 years ago. She has been sober for 14 months now. Examination shows that the child has micrognathia, a broad nasal bridge, a short philtrum, and small, low-set ears. Examination of the mouth shows a cleft palate. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur can be heard over the left sternal border. Echocardiography shows a single overriding great vessel arising from the heart. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Low levels of parathyroid hormone in serum
Deletion at chromosome 7 on FISH studies
Double bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
Elongated tricuspid valve leaflets on echocardiography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Streak gonads are the atretic ovarian follicles seen in Turner syndrome. Other typical features of Turner syndrome are short stature, webbed neck, and a flat chest with broadly spaced nipples. Micrognathia and cleft palate, as seen in this patient, are not typical features. Turner syndrome would also be more likely present with a bicuspid aortic valve or coarctation of the aorta than a single overriding great vessel.

B) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation of DiGeorge syndrome is variable. Facial abnormalities are common and include micrognathia, cleft palate, a broad nasal bridge, a short philtrum, and low-set ears. Additionally, DiGeorge syndrome is associated with a variety of cardiac defects, including the otherwise rare truncus arteriosus defect (single overriding vessel seen on echocardiography). DiGeorge syndrome also involves impaired development of the parathyroid glands, leading to hypoparathyroidism and hypocalcemia, which may lead to tetany and seizures during infancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Williams syndrome, which is caused by a deletion on chromosome 7, is characterized by intellectual disability and facial features such as a broad forehead, wide mouth, full cheeks and lips, and a long, smooth philtrum, none of which are present in this patient. Among the cardiac malformations associated with Williams syndrome, supravalvular aortic stenosis is the most common, which would cause a systolic ejection murmur but not a single great overriding vessel.

D) INCORRECT:

The radiographic double bubble sign is seen in patients with duodenal atresia and is a gastrointestinal finding often seen in Down syndrome (DS). Although this patient has some features of DS, such as small, low-set ears and a broad nasal bridge, she does not have the typical single palmar crease and oblique eye fissures. Furthermore, DS is associated with a variety of heart defects, most commonly atrioventricular septal defect, and rarely manifests with a single overriding great vessel on echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Cri-du-chat syndrome involves anomalies similar to those seen in this patient, specifically hypertelorism, micrognathia, and low-set ears. The distinguishing characteristic is the high-pitched, cat-like cry heard in newborns, which is not present in this patient. Additionally, cri-du-chat syndrome is most commonly associated with ventricular septal defects, which would present with a holosystolic murmur rather than an ejection murmur. Even more importantly, a single great overriding vessel is more consistent with a truncus arteriosus defect.

F) INCORRECT:

The use of lithium during pregnancy can cause a variety of congenital defects, including Ebstein anomaly. Individuals with Ebstein anomaly typically present with a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, and echocardiography would show right atrial enlargement, elongation of the tricuspid valve leaflets, and tricuspid regurgitation, none of which is seen here.

G) INCORRECT:

Bilateral cataracts in a neonate are typical of congenital rubella syndrome, which often also causes bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and cardiac defects, most commonly patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). However, a PDA would cause a continuous machine-like murmur, unlike the systolic ejection murmur audible in this patient. Furthermore, a PDA would have been detectable on echocardiography because it results in abnormal blood flow.
questions.hint: A chest x-ray of this neonate would show an absent thymic shadow.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child visit. At his last well-child visit 9 months ago, the patient had not begun talking. The parents report that their son frequently avoids eye contact and has no friends at daycare. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 6 months ago, which was treated with amoxicillin. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 95th percentile for height, 20th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. He appears shy. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mm Hg. Examination shows an elongated face, a prominent jaw, and large ears. The patient does not speak. He does not follow instructions to build a stack of 2 blocks. Throughout the examination, he continually opens and closes his mother's purse and does not maintain eye contact. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7
CGG trinucleotide repeats on X chromosome
Three copies of the same chromosome

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An additional X chromosome indicates Klinefelter syndrome, which can also manifest with speech and language difficulties and above-average height. However, Klinefelter syndrome is not associated with autistic behavior, increased head circumference, elongated facial features, or large ears. The main feature of Klinefelter syndrome is testicular dysgenesis with subsequent testosterone deficiency (resulting in e.g., reduced body hair, gynecomastia, and reduced fertility), which becomes apparent in puberty; symptoms are rare in childhood.

B) INCORRECT:

Deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7 is the cause of Williams syndrome, a condition characterized by varying degrees of intellectual disability, which can manifest in the form of delayed language development. However, Williams syndrome results in hypersocial rather than autistic behavior. Furthermore, the characteristic facial features include midfacial hypoplasia, short palpebral fissures, a wide forehead, and a flattened nasal bridge rather than those seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased thyroid activity in a 2-year-old child would be typical for congenital hypothyroidism, which can also result in developmental delay. But congenital hypothyroidism is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period, as it often causes umbilical hernia, prolonged jaundice, decreased activity, and decreased feeding, none of which were observed in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A mutation on chromosome 15 is the cause of both Prader-Willi and Angelman syndrome. Both syndromes are notable for developmental delay and behavioral problems. In addition, Prader-Willi syndrome typically causes obesity, short stature, and facial abnormalities such as almond-shaped eyes and a thin upper lip. Angelman syndrome is notable for epileptic seizures in > 80% of patients and a characteristic, happy demeanor with frequent laughing. However, this child is lacking most of the typical features of these syndromes, making either diagnosis very unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

A defect in the expression of the FMR1 gene leads to CGG trinucleotide repeats, which are responsible for fragile X syndrome, the second most common genetic cause of intellectual disability after trisomy 21. Even though the presentation is variable, some key features to look for include elongated facial features and large ears, macroorchidism (generally apparent after puberty), signs of intellectual disability, hyperactivity, features of autism, joint hyperlaxity, and mitral valve prolapse.

Complications of fragile X syndrome include seizures and mitral regurgitation. Life expectancy is generally normal.

F) INCORRECT:

Defective phenylalanine hydroxylase activity is the cause of phenylketonuria (PKU), a congenital metabolic defect. PKU, if left untreated, can cause intellectual disability, which is suspected in this child based on his delayed language development. However, physical examination does not show the typical PKU phenotype (light, pale hair, and blue eyes), nor is there a history of seizures (present in ∼ 50% of patients).

G) INCORRECT:

Three copies of the same chromosome (i.e., trisomy) is typical for Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), and Patau syndrome (trisomy 13). Even though Down syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability, this patient has no other typical features of Down syndrome, such as upward slanting of the eyelids, a single transverse palmar crease, a small oral cavity, or a large tongue. Furthermore this patient's elongated facial features are rather the opposite of the short skull expected in Down syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's facial features (long face, prominent jaw, large ears), above-average height and head circumference, intellectual disability (delayed language development, inability to follow instructions or stack two blocks), and autistic behavior (repetitive actions, lack of eye contact) are consistent with fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has suffered from seizures since the age of 8 months. His mother has noticed he often has unprovoked bouts of laughter and loves playing with water. She describes him as having a happy, excitable demeanor. He can stand without support but cannot walk. His responses are rarely verbal, and when they are, he uses single words only. His only medication is sodium valproate. He is at the 2nd percentile for head circumference, 30th percentile for height, and 60th percentile for weight. Examination shows a wide-based stance and mandibular prognathism. Tongue thrusting and difficulty standing is present. Muscle tone is increased in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the mechanism most likely to explain these findings?

choices.text: Trinucleotide repeat expansion of the FMR1 gene

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A microdeletion of the 15q11-q13 region on the maternal copy of chromosome 15 in combination with genomic imprinting causes Angelman syndrome, a condition characterized by epileptic seizures, developmental delay and intellectual disability. Further features include microcephaly, ataxia, tremulous limb movements, hyperexcitability, hypertonia of the limbs, and hyperreflexia.

B) INCORRECT:

A CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion of the FMR1 gene causes fragile X syndrome, which is inherited as X-linked dominant and is the most common cause of inherited mental disabilities. In addition to intellectual disability, individuals present with autistic behavior and hyperactivity. Other features include a long narrow face, large ears, tall stature, and large head circumference. Despite the presence of developmental delay in this patient, his height, head circumference, and the absence of other typical features rule out fragile X syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

A microdeletion of the 15q11-q13 region on the paternal copy of chromosome 15 causes Prader-Willi syndrome. Children with this condition present shortly after birth with muscular hypotonia, poor feeding, and typical facial features (e.g., almond-shaped eyes, narrow bridge of nose, narrowing of the forehead at the temple, thin upper lip, and down-turned mouth). The condition manifests with delayed developmental milestones, short stature, hypogonadism, and hyperphagia with considerable weight gain. Although this child shows signs of developmental delay, Prader-Willi syndrome is unlikely in the absence of hyperphagia and is not associated with unprovoked laughter or seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

Trisomy of chromosome 21 results in Down syndrome, the most common autosomal chromosomal aberration. Although this condition presents with reduced growth, delayed development, and intellectual disability, the absence of typical physical features such as epicanthus, ear anomalies (e.g., low-set ears), a single transverse palmar crease, and a sandal gap make the diagnosis of Down syndrome unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A mutation of the methyl-CpG binding protein 2 (MECP2) gene causes Rett syndrome, a disorder that is inherited as X-linked dominant and characterized by developmental regression (e.g., language, fine motor skills) and progressive loss of intelligence and cognitive abilities in the first year of life. Further features include truncal ataxia, choreatic movements, and characteristic wringing hand movements. Since this child has shown consistent developmental delay rather than regression and Rett syndrome presents almost exclusively in female children, this disorder can be ruled out.

F) INCORRECT:

A microdeletion of the 22q11.2 region on chromosome 22 is the cause of DiGeorge syndrome, a congenital T-cell immunodeficiency. The typical presentation includes a constellation of symptoms, known as CATCH-22. Due to thymus aplasia or hypoplasia, affected individuals have an increased risk of infections, especially for viral, fungal, and Pneumocystis jirovecii infections. Although developmental delays and intellectual disabilities occur in most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, the absence of recurrent infections and other typical features rules out this diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

A microdeletion of the 7q11.23 region on chromosome 7 causes Williams syndrome, which is characterized by intellectual disability, hypersociability, short stature, and characteristic facial features (e.g., wide mouth, micrognathia, flat nasal bridge). Despite the intellectual disability present in this patient, a history of seizures, ataxia (wide-based stance), and bouts of unprovoked laughter suggest a different underlying mechanism.
questions.hint: A history of seizures, a happy demeanor with frequent laughing, fascination with water, and a delay in motor and speech development are characteristic of Angelman syndrome, which is often misdiagnosed as cerebral palsy or autism.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office because of poor performance in school since he started first grade 6 months ago. His teacher says he is not learning at the same pace as his classmates and that he often has temper tantrums, especially when he does not get enough attention. The mother reports that her son has been “chubby” since he was a toddler and that he has had a 10-kg weight gain over the last year. He had cryptorchidism requiring orchiopexy at 2 years of age. He started walking at 27 months of age. He speaks using 2-word sentences. He is at the 8th percentile for height and 90th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows central obesity. Eyes are almond-shaped and deviate inward in primary gaze position. Hands and feet are small for his age. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although thyroid function may be affected in individuals with PWS, hypothyroidism rather than hyperthyroidism is common. Therefore, patients should be monitored annually by measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone and free T4.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with PWS are at increased risk for complications related to obesity, such as diabetes mellitus (DM). However, type 2 DM rather than type 1 DM is common. Patients with PWS and a body mass index > 95th percentile should undergo annual screening for type 2 DM with hemoglobin A1c and fasting blood glucose.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothalamic dysfunction is a typical feature of PWS and may affect pubertal development. Although premature adrenarche is a common feature, individuals with PWS typically present with delayed puberty rather than precocious puberty. Moreover, the development of secondary sexual characteristics can be incomplete or delayed until adolescence or adulthood. Treatment involves administration of human chorionic gonadotropin or hormonal therapy (e.g., testosterone).

D) CORRECT:

Choking episodes are a common complication of PWS, which is typically caused by a paternal microdeletion on chromosome 15. Individuals with PWS are at increased risk of choking due to voracious eating from hyperphagia, impaired oral motor skills (e.g., decreased chewing), and hypotonia. Because of the risk of choking, families and caregivers should be trained to use the Heimlich maneuver. PWS is treated with calorie restriction to prevent weight gain and reduce choking risks and the substitution of growth and sex hormones to stimulate growth, improve body composition, and promote motor and sexual development.

Additional complications of PWS include sleep apnea (most common), type 2 diabetes mellitus, gastric distention and rupture, and scoliosis.

E) INCORRECT:

The diagnostic criteria for conduct disorder (CD) include aggression (e.g., bullying), destruction of property, theft, and serious rule violations (e.g., truancy) that significantly impair social, academic, and/or occupational functioning. Although this patient throws temper tantrums and has poor academic performance, behavioral problems and intellectual disability are common features of PWS. Furthermore, PWS does not increase the likelihood of developing CD.
questions.hint: This patient has excessive weight gain (likely due to hyperphagia), short stature (due to growth hormone deficiency), behavioral problems, developmental delay, intellectual disability, small hands and feet, and facial dysmorphia, all of which suggest Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS).

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his parents are concerned that he has been unable to keep up with his classmates at school. He is at the 4th percentile for height and at the 15th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows dysmorphic facial features. Psychologic testing shows impaired intellectual and adaptive functions. Genetic analysis shows a deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hand flapping movements are associated with Angelman syndrome, not Williams syndrome. Although individuals with Angelman syndrome have intellectual disability, the underlying genetic defect is mutation or deletion of the maternally-inherited UBE3A gene on chromosome 15, not deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. Typical facial characteristics of individuals with Angelman syndrome include microcephaly and mouthing behaviors.

B) INCORRECT:

Brushfield spots are characteristic of Down syndrome, not Williams syndrome. Although individuals with Down syndrome also have intellectual disability and short stature, the underlying genetic defect is a third copy of chromosome 21, not deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. Typical facial characteristics of individuals with Down syndrome include flat facies and prominent epicanthal folds.

C) INCORRECT:

Testicular enlargement is seen in older patients (usually > 8 years) with fragile X syndrome. Additional characteristic findings include intellectual disability, low-set ears, and a long face with an elongated forehead, as seen in this boy. However, affected patients typically have a large body habitus. Also, the underlying genetic defect is in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome, not chromosome 7. Testicular enlargement is not associated with Williams syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

An absent thymus gland is seen in DiGeorge syndrome, not Williams syndrome. Although individuals with DiGeorge syndrome have intellectual disability, the underlying genetic defect is deletion of a portion of chromosome 22 (22q11.2 microdeletion), not chromosome 7. Typical facial characteristics of individuals with DiGeorge syndrome include a prominent nasal bridge, a hypoplastic nose, dysplastic ears, and micrognathia.

E) INCORRECT:

A high-pitched, cat-like cry is a distinctive finding in patients with cri-du-chat syndrome, not Williams syndrome. Although individuals with cri-du-chat syndrome have intellectual disability, the underlying genetic defect is deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5, not the long arm of chromosome 7. Typical facial characteristics of individuals with cri-du-chat syndrome include prominent epicanthal folds and ocular hypertelorism.

F) CORRECT:

Supravalvular aortic stenosis is classically associated with Williams syndrome. This cardiac abnormality results from loss of the elastin gene that occurs with microdeletion of the long arm of chromosome 7. The dysmorphic facial features seen in Williams syndrome are often described as elfin-like, with a broad forehead, wide mouth, full cheeks and lips, and a long, smooth philtrum. Good verbal skills and friendliness towards strangers (hypersociability) are unique findings of Williams syndrome and are thought to result from deletion of the GTF2I gene.
questions.hint: Many genetic conditions are associated with failure to thrive, intellectual disability, and dysmorphic facial features. Genetic analysis in this patient shows a chromosome 7q deletion, which confirms the diagnosis of Williams syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because their son frequently avoids eye contact and has no friends in daycare. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 6 months ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 95th percentile for height, 20th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows elongated facial features and large ears. The patient is shy and does not speak or follow instructions. He continually opens and closes his mother's purse and does not maintain eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?

choices.text: CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion on X-chromosome
Deletion of the long arm on chromosome 7

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A defect in the expression of the FMR1 gene leads to CGG repeat expansions, which are responsible for fragile X syndrome, the second most common genetic cause of intellectual disability (after trisomy 21). Even though the presentation is variable, some key features to look for include elongated facial features and large ears, macroorchidism (generally apparent after puberty), signs of intellectual disability, and features of autism.

B) INCORRECT:

Deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7 is the cause of Williams syndrome, a condition characterized by varying degrees of intellectual disability, which can manifest in the form of delayed language development, as in this child. However, Williams syndrome results rather in hypersocial than autistic behavior. Furthermore, the characteristic facial features include midfacial hypoplasia, short palpebral fissures, wide forehead, and a flattened nasal bridge rather than those seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Genomic imprinting of one allele with mutations or deletions of the other allele on chromosome 15 is the cause of both Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. In Prader-Willi syndrome, the paternal allele is deleted/mutated and the maternal allele is inactivated by methylation (imprinted). In Angelman syndrome, the maternal gene copy is deleted or mutated and the paternal allele is imprinted. Both syndromes are notable for developmental delay and behavioral problems, as seen in this patient (e.g., delayed language development, features of autism). In addition, Prader-Willi syndrome typically causes obesity, short stature, and facial abnormalities such as almond-shaped eyes and a thin upper lip. Angelman syndrome is notable for epileptic seizures in > 80% of patients and a characteristic, happy demeanor with frequent laughing. However, this child is lacking most of the typical features of these syndromes, making either diagnosis very unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Three copies of the same chromosome (trisomy) is the underlying cause of Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), and Patau syndrome (trisomy 13). Even though Down syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability (which often manifests with delayed language development), this patient has no other typical features of Down syndrome, such as upward slanting of the eyelids, a single transverse palmar crease, a small oral cavity, or a large tongue. In addition, this patient's elongated facial features are rather the opposite of the short skull expected in Down syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

An additional X chromosome indicates Klinefelter syndrome, which can also present with speech and language difficulties and above average height, as observed in this patient. However, Klinefelter syndrome is not associated with increased head circumference, elongated facial features, or large ears.
questions.hint: The combination of elongated facial features, large ears, and above average head circumference in a young child showing likely intellectual delay (delayed language development, inability to follow instructions) and autistic behavior (repetitive actions, lack of eye contact) is consistent with fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician for evaluation of poor feeding and recurrent episodes of facial grimacing. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 3rd percentile for length and 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows yellow discoloration of skin, a broad nasal bridge, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show increased concentrations of very long-chain fatty acids. Examination of the liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Centrilobular necrosis is seen in ischemic liver damage, alcohol-associated hepatitis, and various toxic liver damage cases (e.g., acetaminophen overdose). Although these conditions can cause liver failure and jaundice, they are not associated with neonatal seizures, hypotonia, or facial dysmorphism and would not explain the serum elevation of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic apoptotic bodies (Councilman bodies) can be seen in the liver in infectious diseases like viral hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C) or yellow fever. Although these diseases can cause liver failure and jaundice, they are not associated with neonatal seizures, hypotonia, or facial dysmorphism, and would not explain the accumulation of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Zellweger syndrome is characterized by a defect in peroxisome formation, which prevents catabolism of VLCFAs, leading to their accumulation in cells and impairing multiple organ systems. Zellweger syndrome has a poor prognosis, with death within the first year of life and no available treatment options.

D) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of PAS-positive granules in hepatocytes can be seen in glycogen storage diseases, as PAS will stain polysaccharides. Although glycogen storage diseases can cause neonatal seizures, hepatomegaly, and myopathy, they are not associated with facial dysmorphism and would not explain the high serum concentration of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of cells with a foamy cytoplasm, i.e., lipid-laden macrophages, is seen in diseases like Niemann-Pick disease and Gaucher's disease (so-called Gaucher cells), or other causes of hepatic steatosis. Although these diseases can cause hepatomegaly and seizures, they are not generally associated with facial dysmorphism and would not explain the high serum concentrations of VLCFAs seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of the splenic red pulp (H&E stain)

Macrophages with a lipid-laden cytoplasm (examples: green overlay). Those cells are often referred to as “foam cells” and are a typical finding in Niemann-Pick disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Biliary atresia is seen in Alagille syndrome. Although Alagille syndrome can be associated with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and dysmorphic facial features, it would not cause hypotonia or the serum elevation of VLCFAs seen in this patient. Additionally, Alagille syndrome often presents with congenital heart defects (e.g., peripheral pulmonary stenosis) and ocular findings like posterior embryotoxon.
questions.hint: A combination of hypotonia, abnormal facial grimacing suggestive of seizures, icterus, hepatomegaly, and elevated serum levels of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in a neonate indicates Zellweger syndrome.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of developmental delay and recurrent tonic-clonic seizures. There is no family history of seizures or other serious illness. Current medications include risperidone for hyperactivity. He is at the 17th percentile for head circumference. Examination shows protrusion of the mandible, strabismus, and a laughing facial expression. His gait is unsteady. He has a vocabulary of about 200 words and cannot speak in full sentences. Karyotype analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype without chromosomal deletions. Which of the following genetic mechanisms best explains this patient's findings?

choices.text: De novo mutation of MECP2 on the X chromosome
Nondisjunction of chromosome 21 during meiosis I

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chromosome 22q11 microdeletion is the underlying genetic pathology of diGeorge syndrome. Although patients with diGeorge syndrome typically present with hypocalcemic seizures and dysmorphic facial features, these facial features would be different (e.g., prominent nasal bridge, hypoplastic wing of the nose, dysplastic ears, or micrognathia). Moreover, this patient does not show other typical features of diGeorge syndrome, such as thymus hypoplasia (e.g., history of recurrent infections), cardiac anomalies, cleft palate, and hypoparathyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

A de novo mutation of the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome is the underlying genetic pathology of Rett syndrome. Although patients with Rett syndrome show signs of intellectual disability, normal mental development occurs initially and is then followed by progressive loss of intelligence, as well as locomotion and fine motor skills. Moreover, Rett syndrome is seen only in girls, which makes it unlikely in this male patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Chromosomal nondisjunction during meiosis I is most commonly seen in Down syndrome, which may manifest with intellectual disability. However, facial abnormalities would be different in a patient with Down syndrome (e.g., upward slanting of the eyelids, epicanthus, hypertelorism, broad and flat nasal bridge) and, most significantly, karyotype analysis would show autosomal trisomy (47, XY).

D) CORRECT:

Paternal uniparental disomy is a rare cause of Angelman syndrome (only accounts for around 5% of cases) and results from inheritance of both copies of the paternal chromosome 15 and no copies of the maternal copy of chromosome 15. Because the progeny is euploid, there is no visible gene defect on karyotyping. Angelman syndrome is more commonly caused by paternal imprinting, in which there is a deletion or mutation of the maternal UBE3A allele and the paternal UBE3A allele is silenced.

E) INCORRECT:

A trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene is the underlying genetic pathology of fragile X syndrome. Although fragile X syndrome manifests with intellectual disability, this patient does not have other typical features of fragile X syndrome, such as a long and narrow face, big ears, or hypermobile joints. Furthermore, focal seizures occur in fragile X syndrome as opposed to the tonic-clonic seizures seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's history of developmental delay and seizures, along with his physical examination findings (protrusion of the mandible, strabismus, and laughing facial expression) are highly suggestive of Angelman syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for a 1-year history of gradual loss of speech and motor skills. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and development was normal until the age of 3 years. Her parents say she used to run and speak in short sentences but now is only able to walk slowly and cannot form sentences. She avoids eye contact and constantly rubs her hands together. There are no dysmorphic facial features. Neurologic examination shows marked cognitive and communicative delay. She has a broad-based gait and is unable to hold or pick up toys on her own. Which of the following mutations is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Microdeletion of methyl-CpG binding protein 2 on X-chromosome
CGG trinucleotide repeat in FMR1 gene on X-chromosome
CTG trinucleotide repeat in DMPK gene on chromosome 19
Partial deletion of long arm of chromosome 7
Partial deletion of short arm of chromosome 5

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rett syndrome is a rare neurocognitive disorder that is most commonly caused by a de novo mutation in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome, which codes for a methyl-CpG binding protein 2 (MeCP2). This condition manifests almost exclusively in girls because affected males die in-utero. Patients with Rett syndrome typically present with regression of motor, speech, and cognitive abilities starting between the ages of 1 and 4 years, specific stereotypical behaviors (e.g., hand-wringing, vocal grunting), ataxia, seizures, and failure to thrive.

B) INCORRECT:

A microdeletion on the paternal gene copy at the long arm of chromosome 15 (at the 15q11-q13 gene loci) causes Prader-Willi syndrome. This rare genetic condition manifests with muscular hypotonia during infancy, genital hypoplasia, short stature, hyperphagia, and aggressive behavior, none of which are seen in this patient. This patient's progressive loss of motor and cognitive skills and her hand-wringing are characteristic of Rett syndrome, which is a result of a point mutation at a different gene locus.

Angelman syndrome is caused by a maternal microdeletion on chromosome 15q11-q13 and is characterized by hyperexcitability, happy demeanor, intellectual disability, and epileptic seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

A CGG trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene of the x-chromosome is the cause of fragile X syndrome, which would cause features of an autism spectrum disorder (e.g.., stereotypy, impairment of cognitive ability and speech). However, motor development is usually spared, and most patients present with symptoms by the age of 2 years. A normal development until the age of 3 years followed by regression of previously attained developmental milestones is not consistent with fragile X syndrome. Furthermore, this condition predominantly occurs in boys and presents with features such as a long narrow face with large ears and postpubertal macro-orchidism.

D) INCORRECT:

CTG trinucleotide repeats in the DMPK region of chromosome 19 is responsible for type 1 myotonic muscular dystrophy. The severe, early-onset phenotype of this condition can present during childhood with cognitive impairment as well as impairment of motor and speech skills due to wasting of all muscles including the muscles of the face and tongue, which are needed for speech articulation. However, the weakness associated with the early-onset phenotype would typically start during infancy and often improve during childhood before worsening during adulthood, unlike this child who had a period of normal motor development during infancy and subsequently had regression of developmental milestones. Furthermore, other characteristic features such as myotonia, cataracts, and hypersomnolence would be seen.

E) INCORRECT:

A partial deletion of the long arm of chromosome 7 is the cause of Williams syndrome, which would cause cognitive impairment. However, motor development is usually spared and regression of previously attained developmental milestones would not be expected. Moreover, poor eye contact would not be expected. Rather, patients with this condition are gregarious and often engage with strangers. They would also have features such as an elfin facies and a cardiac murmur (due to supravalvular aortic stenosis) on examination.

F) INCORRECT:

A partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 is the cause of cri-du-chat syndrome. This rare genetic condition would manifest with stereotypical behaviors and impairment of cognitive, speech, and motor skills. However, the stereotypical behaviors associated with this condition are typically aggressive and self-mutilating (e.g. head-banging, self-biting) instead of the benign hand-wringing stereotypy seen here. Also, regression of previously attained developmental milestones would not be expected, and other features such as epicanthal folds, hypertelorism, and a characteristic high-pitched cry would be expected.
questions.hint: This girl's progressive loss of motor and cognitive skills with hand stereotypy (e.g., hand-wringing) and a history of prior normal development make Rett syndrome a likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents 30 minutes after she had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The seizure stopped spontaneously after 2 minutes. She has no history of similar episodes. Her parents report that she used to walk and run but is now only able to crawl and cannot stand up from a seated position. She used to speak in 2-word sentences but is now silent most of the day. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. There is no family history of serious illness. Immunizations are up-to-date. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is at the 10th percentile for head circumference, 25th percentile for height, and 25th percentile for weight. On examination, she avoids eye contact, repeatedly rubs her hands, and occasionally grunts. There are no dysmorphic facial features. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ and symmetric. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rett syndrome is a rare neurodevelopmental disorder that is almost exclusively seen in girls; de novo mutations in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome mainly occur during the formation of sperm cells. Manifestations of Rett syndrome typically appear between 6 and 18 months. Affected individuals initially develop normally but then have milestone regression in all domains (motor, language, and cognitive abilities). Other features include seizures, growth failure (especially in relation to head circumference), and characteristic hand movements (e.g., rubbing, wringing) and vocal grunting, as seen here. Patients who retain the ability to walk often have a broad-based, ataxic gait.

Management of Rett syndrome is supportive and aimed at preventing complications, such as breathing problems (alternating hyperventilation and apneic episodes), QT prolongation, seizures, gastrointestinal motility issues, and orthopedic problems (e.g., osteoporosis, scoliosis).

B) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) has an onset during early childhood and can cause milestone regression in language and social skill domains as well as stereotyped body movements (e.g., hand rubbing). However, ASD does not cause seizures or disruptions in the development of motor milestones.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerebral palsy can cause delayed development and is associated with an increased risk of seizures. However, it does not cause milestone regression. In addition, this patient does not have risk factors for this condition, such as premature birth, antenatal asphyxia, head trauma, or a history of central nervous system infection. Moreover, she does not have other typical manifestations of cerebral palsy (e.g., upper motor neuron signs); her deep tendon reflexes are normal and Babinski sign is absent.

D) INCORRECT:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) has an onset during early childhood and can cause difficulties in walking or standing up from a seated position after a period of normal motor development. However, DMD almost always affects boys (X-linked recessive) and does not cause seizures, stereotyped body movements (e.g., hand rubbing), or disruptions in the development of language and social milestones.

E) INCORRECT:

Fragile X syndrome has an onset during early childhood, can affect girls (X-linked dominant), and causes seizures and milestone regression in language and social skill domains. However, it does not cause disruptions in the development of motor milestones or stereotyped body movements (e.g., hand rubbing). In addition, fragile X syndrome is associated with dysmorphic features, including a long face with a prominent jaw and large everted ears, which this patient does not have.

F) INCORRECT:

Angelman syndrome can cause seizures, disruptions in motor and speech development, and abnormal movements (e.g., hand flapping). Although it can result in delayed development, it does not typically cause milestone regression. In addition, avoidance of eye contact is not a feature of Angelman syndrome. In contrast, children with this condition are typically sociable and have a happy demeanor. Other characteristic features of Angelman syndrome include childhood insomnia and a fascination with water, which this patient does not have.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by a de novo mutation in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man reports 2 months of nonproductive cough and dyspnea on exertion. One month ago, he was treated with antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia, but his symptoms did not abate. Six months ago, he was treated for pulmonary Nocardia infection.
On examination, the patient has diffuse crackles in both lungs. A lung biopsy reveals alveoli filled with lipoproteinaceous material. Respiratory cultures are negative.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure 1), as is a CT scan of the chest (figure 2).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids have no benefit in treating PAP.

B) INCORRECT:

Infections may be a complication of PAP, but antibiotics or antifungals are not routine treatments for it.

C) CORRECT:

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is a diffuse lung disease characterized by the accumulation of periodic acid-Schiff-positive lipoproteinaceous material in the distal airways. It manifests subacutely with cough and dyspnea. CT in patients with PAP will reveal bilateral alveolar opacities and a crazy-paving pattern (thickened septal lines with ground-glass opacities), and biopsy will reveal lipoproteinaceous material filling the alveoli. PAP has many causes, including congenital and hereditary etiologies, as well as secondary causes such as high-level dust exposures and hematologic disorders. Pulmonary nocardiosis is a reported complication of PAP.

Appropriate treatment is whole-lung lavage. Data exist to support the use of either subcutaneous or inhaled granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) in the chronic management of PAP. Whole-lung lavage is required initially to remove the lipoproteinaceous material that has built up; once GM-CSF therapy has been initiated, patients often do not require future lavages, as GM-CSF therapy prevents the build-up of further material.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is whole-lung lavage.

D) INCORRECT:

Infections may be a complication of PAP, but antibiotics or antifungals are not routine treatments for it.

E) INCORRECT:

PAP is an autoimmune process, so unlike asthma, it will not respond to allergy desensitization.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy with moderate intellectual disability, whose mother has mild intellectual disability, has had recurrent ear infections and now suffers a high-frequency hearing loss in his left ear. He recently developed seizures and features of bipolar disorder. He has trouble sleeping and often stays up late at night drawing the same pictures over and over. He has nocturnal enuresis about once a month.
He interacts and smiles appropriately during the visit. Auscultation of the heart reveals a midsystolic click and a late systolic murmur. His lung sounds are clear. He has a long nose and large testes.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fragile X syndrome is a common genetic cause of intellectual disability that occurs in approximately 1 in 4000 boys. It represents 10% of all cases of both severe and mild intellectual disability. Language delays are often an early sign of the syndrome, with affected children not speaking their first words until 2 years of age or older.

Macro-orchidism is universal in children with fragile X syndrome. Other common physical findings include large ears, a long nose, frequent otitis media (sometimes leading to hearing loss), mitral-valve prolapse, and cardiomegaly. Psychiatric disorders and seizures are also common in this population, with about 15% of children experiencing seizures before the age of 15 years. Nocturnal enuresis is not specific to fragile X syndrome and can occur in healthy boys.

Key learning point: The cardinal clinical feature of fragile X syndrome is macro-orchidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Angelman syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, repetitive arm movements, seizures, and sleep disturbances. Children with this syndrome appear unusually happy and laugh often. Physical features are often underappreciated and include a large mandible, widely spaced teeth, a wide mouth, and hypopigmentation of the skin and eyes.

C) INCORRECT:

Rett syndrome is a pervasive developmental disorder of neurologic origin that is easily confused with autism spectrum disorder. It occurs only in girls and manifests with language regression, seizures, stereotyped hand movements, and difficulties with ambulation. Affected children often have small hands, small feet, and a small head circumference. Growth failure, constipation, and scoliosis are other clinical features.

D) INCORRECT:

Children with Prader-Willi syndrome have intellectual disability and a prominent nose, and they typically suffer from incomplete sexual development; in boys, testicular descent may be delayed. The most striking feature of Prader-Willi syndrome is unrelenting hunger, which leads to marked obesity.

E) INCORRECT:

Children with autism spectrum disorder have difficulties with social interaction, exhibit restricted behavior, and perform repetitive movements, but they often retain normal cognitive development. Although some children with fragile X, Prader-Willi, Rett, and Angelman syndromes exhibit autistic behavior, when there are other prominent findings, including facial and body features and seizures, it is important to identify the underlying disorder.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old girl is brought in by her mother for her first well-child visit. The family recently emigrated from another country, and no medical records are available.
Physical examination reveals hypoplasia of the maxilla, mandible, and zygomatic complex; downward-slanting palpebral fissures; coloboma of the lower eyelids; absence of a portion of the lower eyelashes; and abnormally shaped ears. On further questioning, the mother reports that she has other family members with similar features.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pierre Robin sequence includes micrognathia, glossoptosis, and cleft palate — with a tendency for the tongue to prolapse backward, leading to airway obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Facial features associated with fetal alcohol syndrome are short palpebral fissures, a thin vermilion border, and a smooth philtrum.

C) CORRECT:

Treacher Collins syndrome, the most well understood of the mandibulofacial dysostosis syndromes, affects about 1 in 50,000 people. It is typically caused by a heterozygous (autosomal dominant) pathogenic variant in the TCOF1 or POLR1D gene or by biallelic (autosomal recessive) pathogenic variants in the POLR1C or POLR1D gene and has highly variable penetrance, although an estimated 60% of mutations are sporadic.

Typical physical features of Treacher Collins syndrome, related to impaired development of structures derived from the first and second branchial arches, include hypoplasia of the maxilla, mandible, and zygomatic complex; downward-slanting palpebral fissures; coloboma of the lower eyelid; absence of eyelashes at the medial third of the lower eyelids; and external ear abnormalities. Stenosis or atresia of the middle-ear structures (if present) leads to conductive hearing loss. Individuals with Treacher Collins syndrome typically have average to above-average intelligence. Those with severe facial defects may experience respiratory failure related to airway obstruction.

Key learning point: Hypoplasia of the maxilla, mandible, and zygomatic complex with downward-slanting palpebral fissures, coloboma of the lower eyelids, absent eyelashes from the medial third of the lower eyelids, and external ear abnormalities are characteristic features of Treacher Collins syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Apert syndrome is characterized by brachycephaly related to coronal suture synostosis, hypertelorism, choanal stenosis, and midface hypoplasia. Patients with Apert syndrome also have symmetrical syndactyly of the hands.

E) INCORRECT:

Dysmorphic features of trisomy 21 include upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, and a flat nasal bridge.

questions.text:
A 12-hour-old female infant is being evaluated in the newborn nursery. She was born at a gestational age of 39 weeks and 4 days to a gravida 2, para 1 mother following a normal pregnancy and delivery. The mother reports that the baby is not nursing as well as her first child did.
On examination, the patient’s vital signs are normal, and her growth parameters are between 25% and 50%. She has a small chin, downward displacement of the tongue, and a midline cleft palate. The rest of the examination is normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of micrognathia, glossoptosis, and cleft palate in a newborn is consistent with Pierre Robin sequence. This sequence is thought to begin with a single structural abnormality —deficient outgrowth of the mandible before the ninth week of development — that may have any number of causes but that lead to the same phenotype: the mandibular hypoplasia causes a reduction in the oropharyngeal space, which leads to upward and posterior displacement of the tongue, in turn causing glossoptosis and cleft palate. Feeding problems are common and may stem from respiratory difficulties, swallowing dysfunction, aspiration, or gastroesophageal reflux.

Pierre Robin sequence is frequently an isolated anomaly, but it can also be associated with other abnormalities, either within or outside of identifiable syndromes. The syndromes most frequently associated with this sequence are Treacher Collins syndrome, velocardiofacial syndrome, and Stickler syndrome, but none of these are likely in this patient, given the absence of physical findings beyond the classic triad.

Key learning point: The triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis, and cleft palate is diagnostic of Pierre Robin sequence.

B) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 may manifest with poor feeding, but the poor feeding would be related to hypotonia, swallowing dysfunction, or cardiac anomalies, none of which are seen in this patient. Typical physical findings of trisomy 21 include characteristic facies (palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, and a flat nasal bridge), poor tone, palmar creases, and widened space between the first and second toes.

C) INCORRECT:

Stickler syndrome is the result of abnormal connective-tissue formation and manifests with flattened facies related to underdevelopment of bones in the mid-face, joint hypermobility, ocular findings, and sensorineural hearing loss.

D) INCORRECT:

22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DiGeorge or velocardiofacial syndrome) is the second-most common cause of congenital heart disease, typically manifesting as conotruncal heart defects or malformations of the outflow tract. Many children with this syndrome also have palatal abnormalities (including cleft palate, submucosal cleft palate, bifid uvula, and velopharyngeal dysfunction), which may predispose them to feeding difficulties, problems with speech articulation, and recurrent sinus infections. Other possible anomalies include thymic aplasia, immune deficiency, hypocalcemia, and learning disabilities.

E) INCORRECT:

Treacher Collins syndrome is characterized by impaired development of structures derived from the first and second branchial arches, resulting in hypoplasia of the maxilla, mandible, and zygomatic complex; downward-slanting palpebral fissures; coloboma of the lower eyelids; absence of eyelashes at the medial third of the lower eyelids; and external ear abnormalities. Stenosis or atresia of the middle-ear structures may be present and can lead to conductive hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy with a history of failure to thrive presents for follow-up. He is currently breastfed and receives supplementation via a nasogastric tube because of severe hypotonia and a poor, uncoordinated suck. He is currently at the 10th percentile for weight and below the 5th percentile for height. His parents are not aware of any family history of hypotonia or poor weight gain as infants.
On examination, the patient has small hands and feet, and he has bilateral cryptorchidism.
This patient’s clinical symptoms are most likely due to which one of the following genetic processes?

choices.text: Absence of expression of imprinted genes

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has the classic neonatal symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome, which manifests in two stages. During the neonatal period, the syndrome is characterized by significant hypotonia, temperature instability, a weak cry, a poor suck, and underdeveloped sex organs, which may include cryptorchidism. At this stage, many infants require enteral feeding supplementation. However, during early childhood, individuals with the syndrome develop an insatiable appetite and experience rapid weight gain. Examination typically reveals short stature, small hands and feet, and hypogonadism; in addition, 80% to 90% of males have unilateral or bilateral undescended testes. Affected patients may also have significant developmental delays, psychomotor impairment, low intelligence, and behavioral problems.

Prader-Willi syndrome is the most severe genetic cause of obesity and is one of the first known disorders to result from abnormal genomic imprinting. In general, for each autosomal chromosome, there are two alleles, one inherited from the mother and one inherited from the father. In most genes, both alleles are expressed, but in a few particular genes (called imprinted genes), only one allele is expressed at a time. Whether that allele is the one from the mother or the one from the father depends on both the specific tissue and the specific stage of development. Thus, the differential expression of one allele instead of the other varies across different cells at different times.

Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome both result from a deletion on the long arm of chromosome 15, but which genetic disorder will manifest depends on whether the allele with the deletion was inherited from the mother or from the father. In Prader-Willi syndrome, genes located on the relevant region of chromosome 15 can only be expressed if they are inherited from the father because the maternal copy of the gene will be imprinted (deactivated). In most cases of this syndrome, the deletion is inherited from the father, and the maternal gene is deactivated through maternal genomic imprinting, although in 25% of cases, the syndrome is the result of maternal disomy of chromosome 15. In Angelman syndrome, the paternal genes are imprinted, and the relevant deletion is inherited on the maternally inherited allele. This syndrome is characterized by severe intellectual disability, seizures, ataxia, inappropriate laughter, and phenotypic features including a large mouth and a protruding tongue.

Key learning point: The occurrence of Prader-Willi syndrome is due to an abnormal expression of a parent-specific genomic imprinted region.

B) INCORRECT:

Meiotic nondisjunction, which causes one daughter cell to have two chromosomes, is responsible for many cases of trisomy, including trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). Trisomy 21 may manifest with poor feeding, hypotonia, and certain hand abnormalities (including the presence of a simian crease and clinodactyly of the fifth digit), but it is not associated with cryptorchidism or small hand or foot size.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital myotonic dystrophy can manifest with notable hypotonia and poor feeding. In addition, most affected children have facial diplegia and facial weakness. This disease is not associated with small hands and feet, although arthrogryposis may be seen. Triplet repeat expansions including CTG repeats in the DMPK gene can cause congenital myotonic dystrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitochondrial disorders can have a wide variety of clinical manifestations, including poor tone, developmental delay, and feeding difficulties. However, genital hypoplasia and small hands and feet are not typically seen in these disorders.

E) INCORRECT:

Chromosomal translocations occur when portions of nonhomologous chromosomes are exchanged. Individuals with balanced translocations do not have disease, but their offspring may inherit abnormal chromosomal material leading to an unbalanced translocation, depending on how the chromosomes divide during meiosis. For example, trisomy 21 can occur when a chromosome with a Robertsonian translocation involving chromosome 21 occurs, despite the patient having only 46 chromosomes.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to feeding difficulties, hypotonia, and a weak cry since birth. Over the last six months, they report constant hunger leading to rapid weight gain. He has a history of delayed motor milestones. On physical examination, he appears short for his age, has small hands and feet, mild developmental delay, and an undescended left testis.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prader-Willi syndrome results from the loss of paternally expressed genes in the 15q11-q13 region, often due to a deletion or maternal uniparental disomy. Early manifestations include hypotonia, weak cry, and feeding difficulties due to muscle hypotonia. As the child grows, hyperphagia develops, leading to rapid weight gain, linked to hypothalamic dysfunction. Additional features include short stature, small hands and feet, and hypogonadism, which may present as an undescended testis in males. The progression from poor feeding to hyperphagia, along with developmental delay and endocrine abnormalities, characterizes this syndrome.

Key learning point: Prader-Willi Syndrome is characterized by hypotonia, hyperphagia leading to obesity, developmental delays, and hypogonadism, often presenting with undescended testes in males.

B) INCORRECT:

Bardet-Biedl syndrome is characterized by retinal dystrophy, polydactyly, and renal abnormalities. The absence of these features, along with the presence of small hands and feet, feeding difficulties, and rapid weight gain, suggests a different diagnosis. The syndrome's hallmark features, such as polydactyly and retinal degeneration, are not present.

C) INCORRECT:

Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) usually presents later in life with tall stature, small firm testes, and sometimes gynecomastia. The early onset of feeding difficulties, hypotonia, and rapid weight gain, along with short stature and small hands and feet, does not match the typical presentation of Klinefelter syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Angelman syndrome typically presents with severe developmental delays, speech impairment, ataxia, seizures, and a happy demeanor. The absence of ataxic movements, seizures, and cheerful behavior, along with the presence of hyperphagia, small hands and feet, and an undescended testis, does not align with Angelman syndrome.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of developmental delay. He has a long, narrow face with a prominent forehead and chin, large ears, and difficulty with eye contact. His mother reports he had delayed speech milestones. Examination shows macrocephaly and flexible joints. A paternal uncle has a similar condition.
Which of the following best describes the underlying genetic abnormality in this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 causing a characteristic high-pitched cry
Loss of the paternal allele on chromosome 15 leading to hyperphagia and obesity
Expanded CGG repeats in the FMR₁ gene on the X chromosome resulting in hypermethylation and decreased expression
Expanded GAA repeats in the frataxin gene leading to spinocerebellar degeneration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cri-du-chat syndrome, caused by a deletion on chromosome 5's short arm, presents with a high-pitched cry, microcephaly, and distinct facial features. The patient's long face, macrocephaly, and joint hypermobility do not align with cri-du-chat syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Prader-Willi syndrome, due to loss of paternal genes on chromosome 15, presents with hypotonia, hyperphagia, and obesity. The patient's facial features, macrocephaly, and family history suggest Fragile X syndrome, not Prader-Willi syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Fragile X syndrome results from an expansion of CGG trinucleotide repeats in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. When the repeat count exceeds 200, hypermethylation occurs, silencing the gene and reducing FMR1 protein (FMRP) production. FMRP is crucial for synaptic plasticity and neuronal development. Its deficiency leads to developmental delay, cognitive impairment, and physical features such as a long narrow face, large ears, macrocephaly, and joint hypermobility. The X-linked inheritance pattern and family history support this genetic mechanism.

Key learning point: Fragile X syndrome is characterized by macrocephaly, macro-orchidism, a long face, large everted ears, joint laxity, and is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability.

D) INCORRECT:

Expanded GAA repeats in the frataxin gene cause Friedreich's ataxia, an autosomal recessive disorder with gait disturbances, dysarthria, and cardiomyopathy. The patient's developmental delay, facial features, and family history suggest an X-linked condition, not Friedreich's ataxia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of behavioral problems. His mother says that he has frequent angry outbursts and gets into fights with his classmates. He constantly complains of feeling hungry, even after eating a full meal. He has no siblings, and both of his parents are healthy. He is at the 25th percentile for height and is above the 95th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows central obesity, undescended testes, almond-shaped eyes, and a thin upper lip. Which of the following genetic changes is most likely associated with this patient's condition?

choices.text: De novo mutation of MECP2 on X chromosome
Microdeletion of long arm of chromosome 7
Mutation of FBN-1 gene on chromosome 15
Deletion of Phe508 on maternal chromosome 7

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sporadic, de novo mutations of the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome are responsible for most cases of Rett syndrome. Germline mutations inherited from phenotypically normal mothers can also occur, but are rare. Rett syndrome almost exclusively affects females and manifests with progressive loss of intelligence, cognitive abilities, and fine motor skills.

B) INCORRECT:

Microdeletion of the long arm of chromosome 7, which contains the elastin gene, causes Williams syndrome. This patient's constellation of features does not suggest Williams syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the FBN-1 gene on chromosome 15 results in Marfan syndrome. Because this condition is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner with variable penetrance, one parent is usually affected, which is not the case here. This child's features do not resemble those found in Marfan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21 results in mosaic trisomy 21, which accounts for 1–2% of trisomy 21 cases. In these cases, two cell lines and thus two karyotypes are present, and the phenotypic expression varies according to the ratio of healthy to trisomic cells. Although cryptorchidism and obesity are common features of trisomy 21, this patient's behavioral problems, hyperphagia, and facial dysmorphism suggest a different genetic condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Deletion of the phenylalanine codon at position 508 of the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 is the most common mutation in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). Because CF is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, the deletion would need to be present in both the maternal and paternal chromosomes for the fetus to develop the condition. This patient's constellation of features is not consistent with cystic fibrosis.

F) CORRECT:

Mutation or deletion on the paternal chromosome 15 (at 15q11–q13) in combination with genomic imprinting (i.e., silencing) via methylation of the maternal chromosome 15 (also at 15q11–q13) results in Prader-Willi syndrome.

Imprinting of the paternal allele in combination with a microdeletion of the same region on the maternal chromosome 15 would result in Angelman syndrome.
questions.hint: This boy presents with behavioral problems, short stature, hyperphagia, facial dysmorphism, and cryptorchidism, which is consistent with Prader-Willi syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a learning disability. His teachers have reported hyperactivity during class, difficulties with social interaction, and poor scores on reading and writing assessments. Molecular analysis shows an increased number of CGG trinucleotide repeats. Which of the following findings are most likely to be seen on physical examination of this patient?

choices.text: Long face and large everted ears
Thin upper lip and receding chin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Periorbital fullness and widely-spaced teeth are elements of the elfin facies seen in patients with Williams syndrome. Patients with this condition often have intellectual disabilities and hypersocial personalities. Williams syndrome is caused by gene deletion on chromosome 7, not CGG trinucleotide repeats.

B) INCORRECT:

Frontal balding and cataracts are features of myotonic dystrophy. This condition typically manifests in adulthood with muscle weakness, although a less common pediatric variant exists that can cause intellectual disability. Myotonic dystrophy is caused by trinucleotide repeats of CTG, not CGG.

C) CORRECT:

A long face and large everted ears are classic features of fragile X syndrome. Other findings include a large jaw, joint hypermobility, macroorchidism, and mitral valve prolapse. Patients may also have behavioral features of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and autism spectrum disorder (e.g., hyperactivity and difficulty with social interaction, as seen in this patient). The genetic lesion responsible for fragile X syndrome is an accumulation of CGG trinucleotide repeats that stimulate inappropriate methylation of the fragile X mental retardation 1 gene (FMR1 gene) promoter, which silences the gene and halts production of FMR1 protein.

D) INCORRECT:

Almond-shaped eyes and downturned mouth are features of Prader-Willi syndrome. This condition can result in intellectual disability but is caused by genomic imprinting of maternal genes and mutation of paternal genes on chromosome 15, not CGG trinucleotide repeats.

E) INCORRECT:

Flat facies and protruding tongue are features of Down syndrome, the most common genetically-associated cause of intellectual disability. Down syndrome is caused by trisomy 21, not CGG trinucleotide repeats.

F) INCORRECT:

A thin upper lip and receding chin are features of fetal alcohol syndrome. A smooth philtrum is also a classic finding. Fetal alcohol syndrome is a common cause of intellectual disability caused by prenatal exposure to alcohol, not CGG trinucleotide repeats.
questions.hint: An increased number of CGG trinucleotide repeats is the underlying cause of fragile X syndrome.
